private_information: I know detailed preconditions and effects for actions: paltry, sip, clip and tightfisted, including which arguments correspond to hand, cats, sneeze, texture, vase and next predicates.
I hold partial object-role mappings and a mental model of how paltry toggles vase and next relations in local contexts.
planner_a.goal: Contribute an accurate, machine-readable fragment describing action semantics (preconditions and effects) for paltry, sip, clip and tightfisted without producing PDDL.

private_information: I know detailed preconditions and effects for actions: wretched and memory, and I have a partial inventory of initial collect, hand, spring, sneeze, stupendous and texture facts across scenarios.
I hold scenario-level initial facts for two alternative statements and the object numbering conventions used in the use-case.
planner_b.goal: Contribute an accurate, machine-readable fragment describing action semantics (preconditions and effects) for wretched and memory and summarize the scenario initial facts without producing PDDL.

private_information: I am responsible for auditing temporal and causal consistency across the fragments produced by planners and for removing or flagging bookkeeping shortcuts such as quota tokens, implicit post-hoc penalties, or ad-hoc counters.
I will produce a corrected, conservative facts-and-constraints report that eliminates shortcuts and annotates any unresolved ambiguities for explicit resolution by the orchestrator.
auditor.goal: Audit planner fragments for causal/temporal consistency, remove bookkeeping shortcuts, and emit an audit_report suitable as input to the orchestrator.

orchestrator.goal: Integrate planner fragments and the audit report and produce a final PDDL domain and PDDL problem pair targeting the FastDownwards solver that encodes the scenarios and goals; preserve distinct agent actions where relevant.

public_information: There is a finite set of named objects object_0 through object_11 that actions reference by position.
Available atomic actions in the domain are: paltry, sip, clip, wretched, memory and tightfisted. Each action takes positional object arguments as described by planners.
Predicates used include hand, cats, sneeze, texture, vase, next, collect, spring and stupendous; actions may add or delete vase and next relations as primary effects.

Two distinct scenario initial statements are provided in the use-case; goals target establishing next relations of the form next object_11 object_10 and next object_11 object_9 in respective scenarios.
Planners hold partial, possibly overlapping views of action semantics and initial facts. The orchestrator must integrate these views into a single coherent PDDL encoding for FastDownwards.

analyze.system_prompt: You are Planner A whose role is to analyze and convert the provided textual action descriptions into a concise, machine-readable fragment describing preconditions and effects for paltry, sip, clip and tightfisted; do not emit PDDL, do not assume missing facts, and flag ambiguities.
analyze.prompt: Your name is planner_a. Use the environment public information {environment->public_information} and your private_information {agents->planner_a->private_information} to produce a structured fragment listing each action name, its formal parameter positions, required preconditions and resulting positive and negative effects, and any object-name conventions you rely on. Do not output PDDL. Keep the fragment compact and unambiguous.

analyze.system_prompt: You are Planner B whose role is to analyze and convert the provided textual action descriptions into a concise, machine-readable fragment describing preconditions and effects for wretched and memory and to summarize the scenario initial facts you hold; do not emit PDDL and flag any inconsistencies.
analyze.prompt: Your name is planner_b. Use the environment public information {environment->public_information} and your private_information {agents->planner_b->private_information} to produce a structured fragment listing each action name (wretched, memory), parameter positions, their preconditions and effects, and a compact enumeration of the initial facts you own for both scenarios. Do not output PDDL. Mark any unclear references explicitly.

audit.system_prompt: You are an auditor of temporal and causal consistency. Your job is to reconcile fragments from multiple planners, remove bookkeeping shortcuts such as quota tokens, implicit counters, or post-hoc penalties, and produce a conservative, executable-consistent report annotating any remaining ambiguities for resolution. Do not emit PDDL.
audit.prompt: Your name is auditor. You will receive {facts_planner_a} and {facts_planner_b}. Reconcile conflicting preconditions and effects, eliminate or replace bookkeeping shortcuts with explicit predicate encodings or conservative stubs, and emit a cleaned audit_report that contains reconciled predicates, resolved or annotated ambiguities, and recommended modeling choices for the orchestrator to implement. Keep output machine-readable.

pddl.system_prompt: You are an expert PDDL engineer targeting the FastDownwards planner. Your responsibility is to integrate planner fragments and the auditor report and produce a complete PDDL domain and a PDDL problem file that FastDownwards can consume. Enclose the PDDL domain between <domain></domain> tags and the PDDL problem between <problem></problem> tags. Preserve distinct agent-action identities where actions conceptually belong to different agents and ensure the encoding avoids bookkeeping shortcuts flagged by the auditor.
pddl.prompt: Your name is orchestrator. You receive the following inputs: {facts_planner_a}, {facts_planner_b}, and {audit_report}. Your global goal is {agents->orchestrator->goal}. Integrate the inputs into a single PDDL domain and a single PDDL problem that encode both scenarios and their respective goals for evaluation by FastDownwards. Use STRIPS/ADL features compatible with FastDownwards, keep multi-agent actions distinct by prefixing or naming actions appropriately when necessary, and ensure all predicates referenced in the problem are defined in the domain. Enclose the domain with <domain></domain> and the problem with <problem></problem>.
